METHOD: SELF-REPORTS, SUCH AS VERBAL PROTOCOLS, SELF-RATINGS, DIARIES
Description of method:
Obtain participants’ reports of own cognition in progress or as recollected.
Validity of causal inferences: random assignment of subjects:
Not applicable.
Validity of causal inferences: experimental control of independent variables:
Probably not.
Samples: size:
Probably small.
Samples: representativeness:
May be representative.
Ecological validity:
Maybe; see strengths and weaknesses.
Information about individual differences:
Yes.
Strengths:
Access to introspective insights from participants’ point of view, which may be unavailable via other means.
Weaknesses
Inability to report on processes occurring outside conscious awareness;
Verbal protocols & self-ratings: Data gathering may influence cognitive processes being reported;
Recollections: Possible discrepancies between real-time cognition and recollected cognitive processes and products.
Examples:
In a study of mental imagery, Stephen Kosslyn and his colleagues asked subjects to keep a week-long diary recording all their mental images in each sensory modality.

METHOD: CASE STUDIES
Description of method:
Engage in intensive study of single individuals, drawing general conclusions about behavior.
Validity of causal inferences: random assignment:
Highly unlikely.
Validity of causal inferences: experimental control:
Highly unlikely.
Samples: size:
Almost certain to be small.
Samples: representativeness:
Not likely to be representative.
